intro: Trichosandra borbonica var. apiculata, commonly known as the Madagascar yew, is a rare and unique plant native to Madagascar. It is a member of the Taxaceae family, which includes true yews, and is characterized by its distinctive, scale-like leaves and coniferous appearance. The plant produces small, reddish berries that are toxic to humans and animals. It thrives in shaded, moist environments and is often found in humid, tropical forests. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
